description.info: Picked up GoLang! I'm gonna be using it at Qualtrics this Summer, so I'm excited to start hacking with it!
After weeks of putting it off and CTC warranting I learn it, I finally picked up ReactJS!

A great course that I would recommend to anyone at USC. The course essentially clarifies a lot of the lower level activities that are typically abstracted in other courses. Learned topics like data storage, caching, paging, processes, etc.
A look into the world of software management and development lifecycles. Learned about some interesting development paradigms and got to build some interesting projects.
I finally realized NodeJS is the one, true, master framework. I decided to pick it up to supercharge my smaller scale webdev side projects.

Boy this was a doozy of a course. I decided to take the 'hard but educational' professor's version of the course and yes, I later realized that summary of his course was very accurate. I had a fun time in the class though, it literally felt like my brain was being itched while solving some of the problems.

A really cool course! It definitely heightened my understanding of Java and introduced me to a couple of higher level programming concepts that I hadn't really worked with before. I got a lot more experience in multi-threaded, web, and scalable programming.
Got to take a cool course in USC's EE department, where I had to learn C for Arduino microprocessor programming.

I had a blast with this class! It felt like I was playing rather than taking a college class, but I still got to learn a lot about embedded systems. Would highly recommend. Shoutouts to Mark Redekopp.

description.emphasis: CSCI170 - Discrete Methods in Computer Science
description.info: I took this course in tandem with CSCI104 and boy was that a dark time. It was the first time I had ever taken a discrete course so it definitely took some getting used to.

description.emphasis: CSCI104 - Data Structures & Object Oriented Programming
description.info: By far my favorite class thus far at USC. It was a great transition from introductory programming to more advanced design and consideration.

Truly a pivotal moment in my CS career. To give you some context, I was saving multiple versions of projects/assignments/whatever locally as gems like 'project1_1', 'project1_final', 'project1_updated', etc. Picked up git basics around this time and I've been continuously improving my git workflow ever since!
Around this point I started looking into exploring different kinds of programming. Web programming caught my eye.
It felt like a pretty good time to start getting familiar with shell operation so I started learning shell commands and scripting!
I picked up C++ in USC's introductory programming course and data structures course.
I took summer classes at UC Berkeley during this time. Fun fact I wasn't actually enrolled in CS courses, I just figured out where/when they were held and snuck in.
I started my Computer Science journey with Java in my high school's AP CS course!
